Article.Abstract: The identification of ricin toxin A-chain (RTA) epitopes and the molecular context in which they are recognized will allow strategies to be devised that prevent/suppress an anti-RTA immune response in patients treated with RTA-based immunotoxins. RTA-specific human T-cell lines and T-cell clones were produced by in vitro priming of PBMC. The T-cell clones used a limited set of Vbeta chains (Vbeta1, Vbeta2 and Vbeta8) to recognize RTA epitopes. The use of RTA deletion mutants demonstrated that T-cell lines and T-cell clones from three out of four donors responded to RTA epitopes within the domain D124-Q223, whereas one donor recognized the region I1-D124. The response to RTA peptides of T-cell lines and T-cell clones from two donors allowed the identification of immunogenic segments (D124-G140 and L161-T190) recognized in the context of different HLA-DRB1 alleles (HLA-DRB1*0801, and HLA-DRB1*11011 and B1*03011, respectively). The response to L161-T190 was investigated in greater detail. We found that the HLA-DRB1*03011 allele presents a minimal epitope represented by the sequence I175-Y183 of RTA, whereas the HLA-DRB1*11011 allele presents the minimal epitope M174-I184. RTA peptides and an I175A RTA point mutant allowed us to identify I175 as a crucial residue for the epitope(s) recognized by the two HLA-DRB1 alleles. Failure of T-cell clones to recognize ribosome inactivating proteins (RIPs) showing sequences similar but not identical to RTA further confirmed the role of I175 as a key residue for the epitope recognized in the context of HLA-DRB1*11011/03011 alleles.
Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of ricin A-chain HLA class II-restricted epitopes by human T-cell clones.
Article.Affiliations: Section of Immunology, Department of Pathology, University of Verona, Italy.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Epitopes;HLA-DR Antigens;HLA-DR3 Antigen;HLA-DRB1 Chains;HLA-DRB1*11:01:01 antigen;Immunotoxins;Peptide Fragments;Ricin
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Clone Cells; Epitopes; Genes, T-Cell Receptor alpha; HLA-DR Antigens(immunology); HLA-DR3 Antigen(immunology); HLA-DRB1 Chains; Humans; Immunotoxins; Molecular Sequence Data; Peptide Fragments(immunology); Ricin(immunology); T-Lymphocytes(immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Helper-Inducer; Vaccination

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide sequence represents an author-deduced epitopic region based on results from overlapping peptide studies.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Blood was obtained from normal volunteers with no history of previous sensitization to RTA and with no evidence of anti-RTA antibodies in their serum, as evaluated by ELISA.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Positive responses were shown with both a T-cell line and a T-cell clone derived from a single healthy individual. MHC restriction was determined by inhibition assays with monoclonal antibodies directed against HLA-DR, HLA-DP, and HLA-DQ molecules with PCR-typed antigen presenting cells. The authors deduced the peptide sequence based on responses to overlapping peptides.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Deletion mutant studies showed that the Isoleucine residue in position 175 was critical for the immune response.
